com.cubeia.firebase.api.service
Interface Service

All Superinterfaces:
Initializable<ServiceContext>, Startable
All Known Implementing Classes:
JDBCLoginService
public interface Service
extends Initializable<ServiceContext>, Startable

A service is defined per server within the firebase cluster. It exposes its contract to all server members such as core modules, games and other services. A service is:

  • singleton - The server will only instantiate one class of the particular service.
  • thread safe - A service must be able to handle concurrent threads.
  • contract - Implements this interface and a contract extension
Life cycle
A service will be instantiated and controlled by the server. It will only be instantiated once. The life cycle follows that of the $Initializable and $Startable interfaces. In short the a life cycle looks like this:

  1. init
  2. start
  3. <running>
  4. stop
  5. destroy
Concurrency
As a single instance of a service will be responsible for the entire server and its node stack, inluding all games, it must be thread safe. Importantly, this applies even to the $stop and $destroy methods. This is because long running tasks may not be interrupted correctly when the server shuts down, thus arriving after the service has legally been shut down. At the least, a service must not, if such requests are encountered, under any circumstances block the calling thread and thus causing the entire server to hang during the shutdown sequence.

Contract
This interface is the internal service contract and will not be seen by users of the service. A separate contract should be implemented which will be what is actually exposed to calling members as the external interface. Ie., the minimal steps needed to create a service are these:

  1. Create an interface extending Contract which contains the services business methods.
  2. Create a class which implements this interface as and the new interface declared in #1.
Services are packaged in separate archives and has their own dependencies and class loader isolation. Please refer to the developers manual for information.

Service Dependencies: Services must not try to interact with each other during initialization as the server do not guarantee startup order. Should a service depend on another service during initialization it must declare so in its descriptor, please refer to the developers manual for more information.

Author:
lars.j.nilsson
